conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to analyze the work done by the external environment on the gas during the process from C to A.
The work done by the external environment is given by the area under the p-V diagram for the process C to A.
Identify the processes and their characteristics.
A to B is an isobaric process (constant pressure).
The work done during an isobaric process is given by W = P ΔV.
P_AB = 4 × 10^5 Pa, V_A = 2 L, V_B = 2 L (same as V_A).
Work done in A to B is W_AB = P_AB ΔV_AB = 4 × 10^5 × (V_B - V_A) = 4 × 10^5 × (2 - 2) = 0 J.
Identify the process B to C.
B to C is an isochoric process (constant volume).
The work done during an isochoric process is W = 0 because there is no change in volume.
V_B = V_C = 2 L.
Work done in B to C is W_BC = 0 J.
Identify the process C to A.
C to A is an isothermal process (constant temperature).
The work done during an isothermal process is given by W = nRT ln(V_A/V_C).
The temperature at state A is T_A = 200 K.
Since the process is isothermal, P_A V_A = P_C V_C.
From the diagram, P_A = 1 × 10^5 Pa and V_A = 2 L.
At state C, P_C = 2 × 10^5/V_C.
From the diagram, V_C = 5 L.
